status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

worklogs.comment:
Dandandan opened a new pull request #9823:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9823


   Utilize `Buffer::from_trusted_len_iter` to speed up `to_array_of_size`.
   
   This gives about 5-10% improvement on query 6 of TPC-H (in memory) `~8.1 ms` vs `~9ms`.


--

jorgecarleitao commented on a change in pull request #9823:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9823#discussion_r603024245



##########
File path: rust/arrow/src/array/array_primitive.rs
##########
@@ -112,6 +112,22 @@ impl<T: ArrowPrimitiveType> PrimitiveArray<T> {
         );
         PrimitiveArray::from(data)
     }
+
+    /// Creates a PrimitiveArray based on a constant value with `count` elements
+    pub fn from_value(value: T::Native, count: usize) -> Self {

Review comment:
       What do you think of making it `from_trusted_len_values_iter` or something like that, and pass `(0..count).map(|_| value)` to it? This way we do not restrict the function to the specific use-case where the value is constant, and allow more complex behavior to the user.




--

     }
+
+    /// Creates a PrimitiveArray based on a constant value with `count` elements

Review comment:
       I can see the benefits, the downside of this would be exposing an extra `unsafe` method to the arrow crate.

jorgecarleitao commented on a change in pull request #9823:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9823#discussion_r603033807



##########
File path: rust/arrow/src/array/array_primitive.rs
##########
@@ -112,6 +112,22 @@ impl<T: ArrowPrimitiveType> PrimitiveArray<T> {
         );
         PrimitiveArray::from(data)
     }
+
+    /// Creates a PrimitiveArray based on a constant value with `count` elements
+    pub fn from_value(value: T::Native, count: usize) -> Self {

Review comment:
       `unsafe` is not inherently bad, it is just used to flag developers that an API requires assumptions beyond what the compiler can prove.
   
   This crates' whole design embraces unsafe public APIs not marked as `unsafe`, which is bad, so this seems negligible to me.
   
   My understanding is that we need this `unsafe` because `TrustedLen` is still unstable.




--

jorgecarleitao commented on a change in pull request #9823:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9823#discussion_r603207513



##########
File path: rust/arrow/src/array/array_primitive.rs
##########
@@ -112,6 +112,22 @@ impl<T: ArrowPrimitiveType> PrimitiveArray<T> {
         );
         PrimitiveArray::from(data)
     }
+
+    /// Creates a PrimitiveArray based on a constant value with `count` elements
+    pub fn from_value(value: T::Native, count: usize) -> Self {

Review comment:
       FWIW, I tried introducing `unsafe trait TrustedLen` on this crate and arrow2, so that we could declare `fn from_trusted_len<I: TrustedLen + Iterator>`, but I got hit by another unstability.
   
   Essentially `0..10` is a `Range<A: Step>` and `Step` is `unstable`, which means that we can't implement our own `impl<A: Step> TrustedLen for Range<A: Step>` to enable ranged iterators on it. This is being tracked on Rust's side here: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/42168




--

Dandandan commented on a change in pull request #9823:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9823#discussion_r604014389



##########
File path: rust/arrow/src/array/array_primitive.rs
##########
@@ -112,6 +112,22 @@ impl<T: ArrowPrimitiveType> PrimitiveArray<T> {
         );
         PrimitiveArray::from(data)
     }
+
+    /// Creates a PrimitiveArray based on a constant value with `count` elements
+    pub fn from_value(value: T::Native, count: usize) -> Self {
+        // # Safety: length is known
+        let val_buf = unsafe { Buffer::from_trusted_len_iter((0..count).map(|_| value)) };

Review comment:
       `take` implementation also needs a counter value to limit the nr of values. https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/core/iter/adapters/take.rs.html#35
   So ot seemed to me slighty easier implementation (but repeat + take is also looks fine to me, you could argue that that is a better fit as well). As you can see it was using `repeat(*value).take(size))` in an earlier version in datafusion.
   
   I'm not sure if there is any difference in compiled code, can run it through godbolt to see what is changed. I think `iter::repeat(value).take(count)` would be slightly harder to optimize to a efficient loop, but could very well be that the generated code is very similar.




--
